reviews.review:
Must-play if you like first-person puzzle games.
Must-play if you like puzzle games.
Must-play if you like games.
Must-play if you don't like games.

Story and puzzles are just as great as in the first game, if not better.
Several new and easy to grasp mechanics have been introduced. 
The Singleplayer campaign is also much longer, clocking at around eight hours. 
In addition, there is a two-player cooperative campaign just as extensive. A blast to play with a friend.
On top of that, in the workshop you can play (basically) infinitely many user-created maps, both Singleplayer and Cooperative. The community is still active, with thousands of maps created each month. 
(Note: sorting these maps by most popular gives you a good overview of [b]some[/b] of the best maps there, but you can also look up curated lists of maps with great puzzle design, for example RedSilencer's "Introduction to the Workshop" for Singleplayer.)

I'm not even so far on this game but I have to admit that this is one of the best video games I've EVER played. The graphics are excellent, the story is interesting and the humour is on point. The puzzles are neither too hard nor too easy. Portal 1 was awesome and this is just even more awesome.

Portal 2 may very well be the best first-person shooter of the decade it released. The sequel to the legendary Portal, which used incredible mechanics and a fair share of dark humor to captivate its players, Portal 2 simply improved on an already amazing title and literally made it perfect. Unlike the original, which focused primarily on the puzzling tests, this game also featured an incredible story, following the end of Portal. The mechanics alone make a great game, regardless of the way they are used: with your Aperture Laboratories Portal Gun, your protagonist (named Chell) can teleport in marvelous ways. Left click on the mouse, and a blue portal will shoot from your gun and land on the nearest wall, if it is portal conducting. Right click, and an orange portal will come out. You can now walk through either portal and teleport to the other. Some very fascinating concepts spring from this. For instance, if you drop from a ledge and fall into the blue portal on the floor, and you have an orange portal on the wall, you can fly out of the orange at a very fast speed onto another ledge.
The fully voice acted characters are quirky, fully formed, and at times, [REDACTED].
Honestly, the game is worth much more than $10, considering the sheer amount of work it took to create, the replayability, the entirely different co-op campaign, and the endless stream of community levels, plus the easy to use level creator, and of course, the lovely song sung by GladOs at the end.


If you cannot tell already, this game is something you must play. I mean, if you have the devotion to read this entire review, even this tidbit at the end, then you must be thinking about purchasing Portal 2.





Get it.





What more do you want? I gave you a review. It's a perfectly good game. Now you know.





Okay, man. Fine. I'll tell you.





Here it is.





[REDACTED]





There.
